author: Michael Osipoff
title: Valparaiso ready for official tipoff of men's basketball practice - Post-Tribune
text:
There have been "offseason" workouts.
There was a foreign tour to Canada, providing an opportunity to get a jump-start on the proceedings.
And on Friday, the season begins, as Valparaiso holds its first official practice.
Expectations are extremely high for the Crusaders, who broadly have been tabbed as a "mid-major" to watch in 2015-16.
Horizon League favorite. Maybe even win a game — or maybe even more — in the NCAA Tournament.
The Crusaders return, like, a gazillion percent of their production in every major statistical category from last season's team that pushed Maryland to the limit in the Round of 64.
OK, that's not quite true.
But with the NCAA granting Vashil Fernandez, the league's reigning Defensive Player of the Year, a final season of eligibility, they return 98.8 percent of their scoring. And 98.8 percent of their rebounding, 99.5 of their assists, 100.0 of their steals and 97.5 of their blocked shots.

(Steve Millar) That is to say, the only player they lost was David Chadwick, considered a team leader but whose career was short-circuited by multiple knee injuries.
Alec Peters, the likely preseason front-runner for Horizon League Player of the Year, is part of a deep, talented and versatile roster.
"I'm looking forward to everything," Valparaiso coach Bryce Drew said. "Even though we have a lot of the same players, there's always a different dynamic. We're still going to be learning about our team. I'm looking forward to that process with the guys, and seeing which guys catch a rhythm together."
The Crusaders add three "new" scholarship players to that mix.
The lone freshman is center Derrik Smits, the Indiana All-Star who is the son of former Pacers standout Rik Smits.
Shane Hammink figures prominently, after sitting out last season at Valparaiso following his transfer from LSU. On the trip to Canada, the junior showed his skills as a likely difference-maker.
And point guard Lexus Williams, who started as a freshman, is back. He missed all of last season after tearing his left ACL last August, also breaking his kneecap in January before the Crusaders' game at Green Bay.
"He looks great," Drew said of Williams. "He's cleared to play some, but we can't overdo it. We have to monitor what he can do."
The status of E. Victor Nickerson for the start of the regular season is uncertain. The senior underwent surgery on his right wrist and is expected to be out until November. He also had surgery on his left wrist on June 5.
